title: End cover for 5" PVC fence post used for Travel  Trailer sewer hose storage

description.text:
I needed a place to store the heavy duty sewer dump line for my travel trailer. The swivel fittings would not fit in the 4" trailer bumper (and people say that the moisture will rust out your bumper).  
A piece of 5" PVC fence post fit nicely above my bumper and behind the spare tire. I used pull straps to attach it to the bump. The fence post covers didn't look right for end caps.   
I designed and printed a simple cover that fits inside the ends.

title: Trekking pole to tripod converter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Inspired by http://www.trail-pix.com/ but cheap and plastic. If you're ever heading outdoors with 3 or more trekking poles, and you'd like a tripod, take this instead! Just add your favourite ball mount (I sized it for the Joby ballhead X) and a 1/2" long 1/4-20 hex bolt, and 3 trekking poles. At ~50g printed with PLA @20% infill, this is WAY lighter than your average tripod. Let me know if you have any comments!

I printed in PLA with 20% infill, and no supports using simplify 3d and my rigidbot with e3d v6 hot end.   
Just drop the bolt in, screw your ball head on top (I had to use the 1/4-20 to 3/8-16 adapter that came with my ball head) and slide 3 trekking pole tips into the tapered openings. Great for astrophotography from the back country.

description.text: A little holder for all the Novena - "Just The Board" buyers to help hold your hard drive in place until you finish making your own case.

mount as specified in screenshot

The filament holder can be used to hold in place a piece of cloth to clean the filament before it is extruded  
You can split the filament holder in two and clamp it around the horizontal rods using the small screw holes. This way you can install/remove the filament holder without unmounting the whole setup each time.

remixed_from.title: Mk8 Spring loaded Drive Block Replicator 1 / Duplicator 4 / FlashForge / CTC

title: Extruder for FolgerTech Prusa i3 (v-groove bearing and flat feeder)

description.text:
This extruder is a great improvement for your Replicator-type closed extruder! It has been remixed from the direct replacement (original was set up for a smooth bearing and a hobbed feeder) to fit the FolgerTech Prusa i3 (or any other that has a v-groove bearing and a flat feeder).  
I have also added a small finger rest to serve as a leverage point. This  solves two problems with the original design 9as installed on my printer): No more accidentally pinching the hot end mounting block (ouch!) or putting downward pressure on the X-carriage when changing filament.

STL files are included for left-hand models (as equipped on FolgerTech Prusa i3) or right-hand models. You can also print both for use in dual extruder setups. The installation uses the following heardware: 1x grooved bearing (from your old extruder)
1x M3x5 (or a bit longer) countersink screw to mount the extruder to your stepper
1x M3x10 countersink screw to mount the bearing
1x M3x20 (or a bit longer) to mount the lever to the base/stepper
1x 8mm diameter compression spring to provide tension The spring is available in a kit from Home Depot. You'll need to cut about 1/4 of it off.
http://www.homedepot.com/p/Unbranded-Zinc-Plated-Compression-Springs-6-Pack-16087/202045468

comments.author: genbod

comments.text: Warping is caused by the temperature between lower layers and the ambient air temperature being too far apart. When printing with ABS, the bed temps are MUCH higher than room/air temperature, which leads to the cooler upper layers contracting, thus peeling the edges upward from the bed.
comments.author: genbod

comments.text: This was fantastic information!  I ended up adding a space heater, and adding skirting and a raft.  The whole thing printed out perfectly!  Thank you so much.  I did have issues removing the raft from the piece.  I ended up just sanding it down.  It seems like other rafts I have used on other printers came off easier.  I imagine the same issue would happen with super-imposing the disk.  Do you have any more information or suggestions on that technique?  Thanks again for the help.  Your information was exactly what I needed so I didn't end up blindly upping the bed temperature which would have just compounded the issue.
comments.author: MindRealm

comments.text: I only print in PLA, so I rarely have problems with the corner lifting. The only problem is printing long-duration objects where the bottom layer just sits there and cooks for several hours. Then I might add discs under any corner that is sharper than 90 degrees. This is done in almost any software that will allow you to edit STL files. I use FreeCAD mostly. You can either create small discs to put 'under' each corner, or just use the skirting in the slicing software.

comments.text: I ended up putting arctic silver between the heat brake and the heat sink before I put it back together and it's helped a lot with the clogging. I think part of the problem it the fact the heat brake it attached to the motor, as the motor heats your fighting the hot end and motor, and the plastic gets too warm, turns flexible and clogs.... "proof" of this for me was when I couldn't extract the filament (jammed in reverse). Since adding the thermal compound I haven't had a single problem with heat. Hopefully this will solve the last problem with the extruder :)

This small gear holds the hex nuts that are used to adjust bed leveling.  
They allow a better grip when adjusting the bed, and prevent the nuts from rotating with vibrations.  
If the hex hole is too tight for the nut, heat up the nut with a soldiering iron and push it into place (carefully). It should melt the ABS and get melted into place perfectly. Let it cool before touching it ! Also a standard soldiering iron (~300°C) is good for ABS but might be too hot for PLA.

description.text:
Elaborate case for RAMPS card  
Designed by Guillaume (Mathers) for Hackens (11/2014)

I made this to see if my printer bed was flat. This is 0.2mm thick with 0.4mm wide lines. This thickness was the lowest I wanted to test for  my Da Vinci 1.0. The width of the lines was the lowest that the slicing software would detect reliably (it takes a lot longer for the slicer to solve this than you would think, 8 minutes plus for me).  
It can take an hour or so to print, but it does look cool once done, almost like a tunnel going off into infinity (thus the name).   
I was able to determine my print bed is slightly convex, or maybe the printer head dips down in the center due to weak support. Either way it also shows if your bed is level with the print head.

This test is for a 200mm X 200mm bed. I only made it 195mm X 195mm because the slicer would not accept it at 200mm on the dot.  
4.5 Degrees center to center (C.T.C.) between each radial line. 10mm C.T.C. of each horizontal or vertical line (except for the innermost lines which are 14.6mm C.T.C. because having 10mm spacing from the outside in leaves an odd number when starting with 195mm plus the 0.4mm line thickness...  
I could be willing to modify this if asked. But just take my SolidWorks file instead.

title: Ocarina of Time Spiritual Stones
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
"Ye who owns 3 Spiritual Stones stand with the Ocarina of Time and play the Song of Time" In Hyrule, during the era of Ocarina of Time, Link's quest involves finding the three Spiritual Stones in order to open the Door of Time which has sealed away the Master Sword in the Temple of Time. The races who protect these Stones will only open their minds to those who know the melody of the Royal Family.
The three stones in the game are known as: the Kokiri's Emerald, the Spiritual Stone of the Forest, held by the Great Deku Tree; The Goron's Ruby, the Spiritual Stone of Fire, a treasure held by Darunia; and the Zora's Sapphire, the Spiritual Stone of Water, held by Princess Ruto.
During his quest to unlock the Sacred Realm and steal the Triforce, Ganondorf, the evil king of thieves, was refused the Spiritual Stones by each of their respective guardians.In response, he cursed them all with various blights using dark magic. In order to obtain the stones to prevent the Triforce from falling into Ganondorf's hands, Link is required to free the guardians from Ganondorf's malevolence. Taken from Dycus
I put the stone in and lined them up in blender, and cut them in half (almost in half) easier to print.

description.text: I needed a larger spool holder for a 2kg spool I bought. Since all the other designs (as of 24th of January 2015) here are not large enough I decided to create this one. It handles a spindle length of 120mm with a small diameter of 32mm. Prints in about 38 minutes. Handles smaller spools like 1kg and the stock ones with shorter spindle and larger diameters. So this is a versatile universal holder :-)

The large spool holder fits into the UP! mini by placing it diagonal and flat on the bed. I used the settings of 0.35mm layer, fast printing, fill: hollow. Since I used ABS I got some warping, but it still works fine :-)
My dad bought a load of sorting boxes from Aldi recently but wanted to be able to hang them up all over the place so I made a hook so he can do just that.

I printed at .25 layers with .35 nozzle and 20% rectinilinear fill.
The dovetails don't work yet and I may end up fixing them at some point - hence it's a "work in progress" for now.
Edit: BoxHook6 now has working dovetails though they are very tight they do work.

This is the Chalk painting mechanism of the "Artist Robot".

the one is to release the chalk gradually as the robot writes because the chalk will be destroyed due to the ground friction, and the second is that the mechanism must constantly push smoothly the chalk holder in to the ground, in order to keep the touch with it, and simultaneously must absolve the shocks and vibrations like a suspension. description.text: Just a simple shelf to be used between two vertical surfaces - for example two wardrobes in the kitchen - to store light things on it. It was designed as a spice shelf. You can read more about it here: http://www.printingin3d.eu/item/shelf We printed one set of it, but didn't use it in the end. We designed a completely different one as you can read on the link.

First, you will need a piece of acrilyc glass. The stl file is build for 6.6 mm thick one - if your one is different in thickness you can download the OpenSCAD files and modify the shelfThick value in the consts.scad file.
After the setup you simply need to print two of them, drill it on and add the acrilyc glass and that's it: you are ready.

UPDATE 1: Made rings fit better in base; strengthened all around. Here is and easy to print, and easy to assemble cable organizer. We use this to keep the wires inside our robot organized. We are working on a modular version so stay tuned! Keep it Awesome
Team 1418 http://www.team1418.org/

Print the file, It contains 1 base, and 8 rings. The base has 8 slots for each of the rings. Push the rings into each slot. The parts are designed for a friction fit so it will be tight. Some sanding and trimming may be needed to get the best fit. *optional: use a little super glue or acetone to secure the rings into the base once they are inserted into the base. You can mount the organizer with screws using the holes in the base. Enjoy, and share your makes! :) Keep it Awesome
Team 1418 http://www.team1418.org/

Updates
07-12-2017 : long time after, here are the new plates that was used in production at the end. The new source is in onshape : https://cad.onshape.com/documents/086229ea796640d29acd68ff/w/2030a3358fd641da896d20a5/e/1e4ef00263ee4eae9316731a
06-08: : plates stl was not manifold in slic3r. Now they have been repaired in netfabb basic. it works everywhere.
06-06: : add some accessories like ramps support . Support for endstopY and some little debugs. It's going more and more clean now to assemble. Thank you to all from the community for feedback.
05-28: version 1.2.2" : some debug of 1,2 + new places for endstop X/Y . X goes under head , so cable can go with the head cables , Y goes on the right wall, fixed. no more danging cables for endstops.
04-10: little update . was alignment problem between Yslides and XYbearings
04-09 : Version 1.2 : Big changes everywhere but extruder :
-> bearingsXY : now fix on the side ,more easy to build and far more solid on the Y rod ( it was breaking too easy)
-> Head : new one piece part , was problem with assembly. when you fix, parts are not aligned and bearings become hard. was not stable enough
-> new inductive support : more solid and lower
-> new slideY : far more solid, Xrods are further away , we have now an iso assembly (allmost)
-> new Zslide : more solid, bigger, we fix the plank with 4 wood screws . no need to counterdrill anymore. 03-13 : new plate 2 : Ztop bearing and GT2 hole too small. The belt was touching the part !
03-06: new plates : reinforced Y support on bearingsXY, screws holes on Yslide, now only one Yslide has endstop support
02-28: new plate2 : ztop was bad oriented.
02-27 : new plates. not necessary to update : holes for jhead support in head was too low for 8mm rod version. update for compatibility. not important for this version 6mm XY rods.
02-27: new plate2 . Jhead attach with inductive sensor was not well oriented on the plate

link to the smartrapcore / smartrap group with lot of accessories :
http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/smartrap

This is the new model out of the http://smartfriendz.com lab ! new video : https://youtu.be/7opAXs0lU5o The video chanel is mixed with our smartrap project. There is not much videos for now about the smartrapcore, but it's coming, especially the full assembly video serie ! This kit is ready to sell and published here , exactly like the smartrap project wich was a frank success on the open source side.. thank you to all ! To have something different from the Smartrap, we started the project from a coreXY base and made it as simple as the Smartrap to assemble and update. The box doesn't have any cut and there is no special or too precise operation to do to assemble this model. Printed elements are simply put on top of the box ans screwed with simple wood srews. The sources are written in code in openjscad and published on youmagine : https://www.youmagine.com/designs/smartcore There will be "certainly" a customizable version here in openscad,
I'm working on it too . Here you can find the stl files for a common choice of elements :
  • 10mm wood
  • Nema17
  • X and Y rods in 6mm and Z rods in 8mm .
    • With the openjscad, you get options for Wood thickness, nema size, rods size , printable size .
    You can choose the "what to show" selector to have :
  • all assembly
  • parts plates to export ( be carefull, it works direct in cura but not in slic3r, you need to repair parts with netfab basic for it )
  • wood and dos sizes ( printed on models ).
  • separate elements.
    • You can ofcourse play with it and edit the file as you want .. the source is quiet clean ( even if scary at first read :) . Soon to come :
  • BOM
  • assembly videos
  • integrated assembly in the openjscad file.

BOM: Wood : 4 planks sized like output in openjscad. Thickness is as you like. Printed parts : please use the output of openjscad related to your parameters Screws: 6 x M3x30 / 6 x M3x25 / 10 x M3x16 / 10 x M3x10 / 5 x M3 nuts / 12 x 3.5 wood screw flat head! / 5 x M8x25 Rods: 4 rods XY , diameter and length like in parameters. 2 rods Z , like in parameters. Stepper motors : 4 ( X Y Z extruder) nema17. Can be 40mm or 48mm length. electronics: can be any reprap electronics. we develop with ramps 1.4. Inductive sensor: LJ18A3-8-Z/BX Hotend: Jhead type. Bearings: 10 x 608zz. 4 lm8uu . 8 lm6uu ( or 12 lm8uu if rodsXY 8mm). Bowden cable: 70 cm . in diameter 2 , out diameter 4. GT2 belt 6mm : around 3 meters . See openjscad related to your parameters GT2 pulleys : 3 x 20 teeth. pressfit : 2 x 4mm with M6 thread.

comments.text: I can confirm the OnShape issue with the motor positions. I'm in the process of assembling mine now and had to change a few things. For the motor mounts, I used Fusion 360 to change the parts from 10mm to 12.2mm (what my plywood was) and now it's fine. My x-axis didn't have enough clearance from the wall, so I ended up redesigning the x-axis sliders to provide more clearance. The OnShape parts are designed around 8mm rods and are half designed around LM8UU's: the width of the linear bearings in OnShape are correct but the length is that of LM6UU's (19mm instead of the 24mm they should be). As such, the top of the hotend block is too small to fit two LM8UUs and you either need to resize it or use different bearings, I'm using some printed bearings for the top and regular LM8UUs for the bottom. The LM8UUs should work fine everywhere else (I'm only using one for the x-axis sliders instead of two, if you use two they'll stick out). I also had to scale the 608zz things up by 1% because they wouldn't fit on my 608zz bearings. Scaling up 1% made them slide right in with just enough friction to keep them in place and I'm not too worried about them coming off during use.

comments.text: The OnShape version uses 8mm rods by default. comments.text: I've had some pretty bad experiences with the Bowden extruder that is included in the SmartrapCore design files with 1.75 filament.  I think this design might be better with 3mm filament, but since 1.75 seems to be a common standard I changed the extruder for the 3Dator Bowden Extruder design.  This has solved my issues with 1.75mm filament on a Bowden extruder and I think it has more to do with capturing the filament path from drive gear to bowden tube with very little empty space for the 1.75mm filament to kink.

comments.text:
Haha :D
Sorry, I'll try to make it more clear.
First you need to make a private copy of the document on Onshape to be able to modify anything. It's on top left corner if I remember correctly. Then open the new document and right click one of the parts, like a Left motor mount for example and select Switch to [FILE NAME]. Then there's a variable on left side called WoodThickness or something, and you can change that. It's in millimeters. After you're done, select the first tabon bottom of the page, "all_standard" to go back to the printer assembly.
This is what I tried the first time, and after I printed the part, it fit the 16mm MDF perfectly, but the motors mounting holes were way off.
So instead I downloaded the original files, unmodified. Then modified them myself using Blender, yes it's a free modeling program. (Not a CAD design program.) You need an addon to be able to edit STL files with it.
Anyway, let me know if that was better! :D
And good luck on your exams!

comments.text: Is it better to print these parts in ABS or PLA? Is there a heat concern for the hot-end mount associated with either material? Thanks!
comments.author: Levictus

comments.text:
Heat won't be an issue. The part where the hotend is attached to doesn't or should I say, shouldn't get hot or the filament will get jammed, that's why there's a fan.
My first printer has all the parts in PLA, even a fan mount that is close to the hotend. The only advantage ABS will have for this application is that it'll be stronger. PLA's strength is enough though.
So my point is, if you're using a 3D printing service to get the parts, go for whichever is cheaper in terms of material.
comments.author: Levictus

comments.text: Awesome, so if abs and pla are priced the same I will go for the abs. Thanks for the reply ;)
comments.author: WhiteRenard

comments.text:
I asked a similar question previously and after surprising replied I've made my hot end assembly out of PLA. Its generally cheaper, friendlier to print and doesn't kill me with fumes. And the parts are working perfectly :)
EDIT: But yes, if possible ABS is most likely preferable for mechanical parts.

comments.text: Fantastic design.  My son and I built a smartrap last year mainly because it could easily be broken down to fit in luggage as he studies overseas and needs the portability.  The smartrap could be built really cheaply and was light and compact.  Your new core machine looks much more rigid and robust and can no doubt be pushed faster.  I'd probably be tempted to fit a brace panel across the front to make the sides more rigid and mount the spool and extruder stepper in the vacant space in front of the bed.  What is the cylinder in front of the extruder hot end? Is it an optical sensor for Z axis endstop and bed autolevelling?  My next machine will be a corexy but I am leaning towards a steel welded frame like my first Prusa Mendel i2 derived machine.
comments.author: nglasson

comments.text:
thank you :)
the sensor in front is an inductive sensor. The glass plate has aluminium tape under . It's indeed for autolevel bed.
The main goal of this new design was to have a more easy to assemble kit and more robust. We're happy about that for now. I print now around 80mm/s and moves are at 150mm/s . Even without a panel in front, it's not moving a lot at this speed.
Evolution of this model seem also more easy.. the goal is to have a full range of "quality" , from the really basic kit as you see now ( the cheapest also i think? ) to more sofisticated models with aluminium box, front panel, raspberry pi inside...etc..etc..
we have a lot of place now :)

title: Boss Remains - Majoras Mask
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: Boss Remains are quest items from The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask. They are masks left behind by the bosses who inhabit the four temples of Termina. Each time Link defeats a boss, he is rewarded with the mask it previously wore. The masks have been cursed by Majora's Mask to keep the Four Giants imprisoned within the bodies of the bosses. When Link acquires one, the Giant that had been sealed by it is freed. Link will retain the Boss Remains even after resetting the three-day cycle, and so the Giants remain liberated. After Link collects all four remains, he is able to summon all Four Giants on the night of the Final Day, allowing them to prevent the Moon from crashing into Termina.

title: Wall Mounts - Simple blocks that let you hang / display / wall mount almost anything.

description.text:
A simple solution that enables you to wall mount / hang things for display that doesn't have any existing way to do it.   
There are two types. Standard and Heavy Duty. Standard is great for smaller/lighter items and where a small size is important so they cannot be seen. Heavy Duty has a larger backing plate, so requires a bigger piece of mounting tape, and is used for larger/heavier things.   
In the example pictured I had a souvenir Boomerang from Australia to mount. It had no facility to do this but these blocks made it easy. The same can be applied to other 'objects you may want to wall mount that do not have any standard mounting facility.   
The download file has two 'wall mounts' that are used in conjunction with regular picture hooks and some high strength double-sided foam mounting tape (available from most hardware stores).   
Once installed you will be able to hang and remove the item as easily as any usual picture from the wall and relocate it if required. To hang in another location you will only need to install new picture hooks in the appropriate places... obviously accuracy helps no different to hanging a picture well.  
As the Boomerang is quite small and lightweight the standard Wall Mounts were ideal.

On a Replicator 2 I've been using 4 shells and 50% fill to make sure they are almost solid so strong...Use Raft to make sure they stay well stuck to the build plate as they are quite small.   
Installation procedure:  
Get some regular picture hooks and high strength (to be safe but depending on the weight of the object being hung)  double-sided foam mounting tape. Most hardware stores have this.   
I recommend a quick wipe of alcohol to clean the flat (mounting) surface of the block before sticking the tape on. This is just to make sure the mounting tape adheres well to the block. The side you need to stick the tape to is flat and does not have an arrow on it. The arrow w side slips onto the picture hook and the arrow indicates "up".  
Close the picture hook angle down a bit so the blocks will still readily slide on/off. By doing this you minimise the width once mounted on the wall but also need to ensure easy removal as all blocks will need to slide off simultaneously once stuck to the back of the wall mounted item.   
Work out the required positing of the picture hooks and install them on the wall. Make sure you take time and care doing this as you are effectively going to tick your object to these points when you install it the first time.   
Place a block over each hook with the backing tape removed from the foam mounting tape.   
Now the fun part... carefully (noting any reference points you may have made) push the item to be wall mounted against the blocks (which have been pre-hung on the hooks). Push the item being mounted firmly to ensure a strong bond with the mounting tape.   
I suggest removing the item from the wall to ensure the blocks are well stuck to it. Done correctly, lifting the mounted item straight up will lift it, blocks and all, off the picture hooks.   
Once removed press the blocks firmly against the item you have been mounting to the wall. Once satisfied the blocks are well stuck mount it back onto the picture hooks... job done.   
This is a simple process. It may sound long and difficult but really no harder than mounting a picture the usual way. However, I have explained the points in detail as you are effectively fixing the item being mounted to some fixed points. Taking care is important to ensure it works well.   
Our Boomerang looks great on the wall.... you could even mount your favourite 3D prints the same way if you like the idea of 3D art on display!

title: nema 17 motor torque combiner and raiser

description.text:
this is a prototype it should raise torque by 9 times as well as combine the torque of 2 motors for a combined end torque of around 80kgs you will need threaded rood 5/16 i believe same as 3d printers
aswell as nuts and washers to match i used 4 custom washers (CW) print 3 large gears
print 5 small gears use locknuts in the motor connectors
use plumbers tape on the rest
rod is from bunnings rest i got from masters will post a proper guide at a latter date for now i can be contacted via skype by adding facebook:dhudd3 (i use Facebook on Skype hence the weird username)

ok so stuff you will need plumbers tape
1 length 5/16 threaded rod
about 30 nuts to suit (or use leftovers etc)
2x locknuts (you could get more and replace some of the normal nuts up to you but can be a pain)
12 608zz bearings
about a 4 washers will do
some long bolts for the nema 23 holes to hold the parts together i found not using the nut holes to join parts 1 2 and 3 worked better than using them up to you(it will hold itself together) start with big gears at both ends (so on the engines and the bottom area where the old engine mount no is (part 3) for custom washers i used 4 on the outside (more details latter) you will need to print the square part (to make our new piece sit at the correct height) and a new version of stl1 (MODSTL1) to allow for bearings more instructions to come but that will at least get you all the things you need the idea is simple 2 motors have small gears which drive one large gear at this point we have combined our torque next we go to another small gear which raises the torque by 3 to another big gear (which starts the reduction) to another small gear (torque increased by 6 now speed reduced by 6) to another big gear (which sets up our reduction again) to our final small gear (we now have a torque increase of (4.5kg2)9 anout 80kg or so with fully powered motors I HAVE NOT TESTED THIS I WILL BE DOING SO IN A FEW MONTHS AS I AM GOING OVERSEAS USE AT YOUR OWN RISK THIS IS MISsING ONE FILE BE WARNED I WILL UPDATE THE THINGI WITH CON2 (to join the threaded rod coming from our motor to the auger)

title: Penrose Triangle Illusion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: !! New version penrose5.stl with a couple of wayward vertices fixed !! This is a 3D-printable version of the Penrose Triangle illusion, based solely on the 1934 design painted by Swedish artist Oscar ReutersvÃ¤rd. The design also appeared on Swedish postage stamps in the early 1980s. I created this 3D design entirely from scratch using the process outlined in the "Instructions" section below. This work is based solely on Oscar ReutersvÃ¤rd's design, although some elements are inspired by the Hollow-Face illusion discovered many decades (if not centuries) ago. This model contains a number of notable improvements over previous 3D representations: 1) It is parallax-corrected for a viewing distance of 40cm, i.e. it will look exactly like Oscar ReutersvÃ¤rd's design, with cubes lining up on all 3 sides simultaneously. This is a great visual improvement over previous versions, which only lined up on 2 sides simultaneously. 2) It has been resized (to 99.43 x 99.65mm) to make maximum use of the Makerbot build envelope. 3) The top edges are now tapered so as to make the most of your printer's capabilities. The better your printer, the sharper the edges will be. 4) I own the copyright to this 3D design, and hereby distribute it under the "Attribution/Non-Commercial/Share-Alike" licence for all non-profit parties to print, improve and share.

Simply print! No support required. NB: I have uploaded a new penrose4.stl file, which has better poly orientation to ensure that the walls build up gradually. There is also now a new penrose4_braced.stl file which includes bracing to help keep the blocks in the right position during the first half of the print! You can create your own Penrose Triangle illusion very easily by following these steps in your favourite 3D software. A photo has been attached for each step. 1) Create an image plane containing the image you are trying to portray. Then create a camera at a suitable viewing distance from the image plane (e.g. 40cm)
2) Create a cube, rotate it so it matches a cube in the image, delete the top 3 faces and then duplicate it 8 times. Lay them out roughly.
3) Viewing from the camera created in step 1, pull the vertices in X and Y until they line up with the image. This corrects for parallax error since we are working from the intended viewpoint perspective, and not an orthographic view.
4) Cut out the bits you don't want, referring back to the image if you need to. Once done, stitch everything together into one surface.
5) Extrude the stitched surface up or down and then widen the bases of each cube if you want. Done! Making your own 3D Penrose Triangle model clearly isn't rocket science. In fact, it would make a very good practice exercise for first-year 3D art/design students!

comments.text: It took me quite a few tries to get this to print properly, even scaled up to 150%, as I had ongoing issues with PLA warping up even with cooling. I wound up resolving the issue by switching from Slic3r to Cura. In Cura, I set the wall thickness to 0.5mm (I have a 0.5mm nozzle on my RRP Mendel), and also needed to use a brim to keep the print on the bed. This is more a limitation of my printer, but I thought I'd mention in case anyone else is trying to solve the same issue.

comments.text: I know this is a late post, and although this sounds odd, the answer to your question is 1, no there is no Star of David in his design so 2, yes, he technically owns the Star of David. There is, by chance, a star of David at the center of the design of you tilt it a certain way. Think of the situation as you folding origami, and making a, say cross with your folds. This is made is Christianity's symbol, but only when you tilt your paper do you find the symbol. Therefore, chance overtakes the legal system, so there is no Star Of David in the design, it is only in your mind, almost like an optical illusion. On that sense, he owns your vision of the optical illusion, so yes, he owns [the file, not your print] the Star of David, science it is part of his design. If someone has any corrections for this, feel free to respond, but I believe I am right in saying that there is no Star of David, but he owns your image of the Star of David. Thanks for reading.

description.text:
This is my first mount for a 600tvl CMOS camera with a servo controlled pitch.  I use the gimbal control from the NAZA-M Lite flight controller on my DJI 550 Flamewheel.  I used FreeCAD for the design. It uses a 7.6 gram servo and a Traxxas 5x10x4mm ball bearing.  The Ball Bearing is pressed onto the post. and the two-piece camera bracket pinches the bearing and the servo's control horn.  
This is a work in progress, as I'm not sure of the performance of this servo.  The rails that support this mount are 12mm in diameter and spaced 68mm apart on center.  The mount is secured with a couple of cable ties.  I'll see if that is sufficient.  
If anyone in interested with adapting this, you're free to use the FreeCAD file.  I'm new at all this, so the FreeCAD file may be a bit confusing.  Good luck.

Designed from scratch using FreeCAD.  Build using PLA and ABS with an E-Flite DS76 Sub-micro Servo and a Traxxas Blue sealed 5x10x4mm Ball Bearing.  
I modeled the 600tvl camera, the servo and the bearing. I used them along with a range of sketches (2D artwork, extruded in shapes) to cut and add to various primitive objects (cubes, cylinders etc.) to create the final shapes.  Added some fillets to round off the edges.  
Exported the shapes as STL files and printed them on an UP! Plus 2 printer.

author: njd13

description.text:
End caps to place on 1/4" carriage bolts for leg levelers.   The metal shelves I'm building have 1/4" nuts welded into the square tubing at the base, these will screw into the base.  
Rev - : This revision is designed to be used with Flexible filament (I used Soft PLA).   It slips over the carriage bolt head with no adhesive required, it's a purely mechanical fit.  You will need to scale as required to get the carriage bolt to slip over the cap.   Print a couple of test pieces at a time until you get the fit that you desire.   115% worked well for the Soft PLA I was using, your mileage may vary.  
Rev A: This revision is designed to be used with ABS or PLA plastic.  The carriage bolt head is bonded to the concave side of the cap using cyanoacrylate glue.  I've been using Loctite Super Glue Gel, but whatever you use, make sure you get a good bond to prevent the cap from breaking free of the carriage bolt.   I also cleaned the carriage bolt heads with acetone before bonding to remove any oil.  
For either design, rotate the cap STL rendering to place the bottom on the build plate

description.text:
Sub-C batterys from RC battery packs or power tools when broken down are not wrapped individually and can be easy to short out.  
i created this jacket shell for sub-c so the anode and cathode are available but protect the top end where a flat metal surface can short the cell.   
there is an inner ridge that clips the jacket onto the cell so that it  will not slide out.  with the top end of the jacket on a surface just push down on the battery until it snaps in.  
I have added a cap version and a shorter 32mm jacket for 3/4 sub-c cells.   
i have only printed in PLA and have not tried joining batteries while in the jackets yet.

with cura
0.2mm layer
0.3 shell
100% fill print with top on plate walls are very thin, careful if you increase the shell that your gcode is still printing solid walls subc_jacket.stl is for a 42mm 1.7" sub-c
subc_jacket_cap.stl is a cap for sub-c with no body
subc_jacket_32mm.stl is for 32mm 1.3" 3/4 sub-c cell

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Locking Extruder Handle

description.text:
This is an Extruder handle that locks in the open and closed position so that you don't have to hold it with your hand the while you change filament on your Printrbot Simple Metal. My motivation for this design came from danmar's original extruder handle. However, I realized that it would interfere with where my RPi camera for Octoprint was mounted since the handle protruded out so far. When my simple would have tested the leveling of it's bed the handle wouldve hit the camera. So, I tried shortening his handle on his design quite a bit and that even hit the camera. So I thought about another possible way to make the handle work, when after contemplating multiple ideas I came up with this Locking version. And NOT ONLY does it lock but it DOESN'T hit my RPi camera!!!!!! I designed one version of the handle that will hold a dust filter designed by Creative Tools (it is the one shown in the photos).
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:492067

Print all three parts (only one of the main piece depending on the dust filter option) Assemble the Handle with three M3 20mm screws, (same ones used on the simple metal, I got mine from my kits leftovers). Print a Dust Filter for your handle if you decided to go with the Dust Filter option. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:492067 I highly suggest printing one for each spool you have so that you do not have to monkey with getting filament through the filter each time. And, they don't take long to print anyway! :)

description.text: No support required, parts are easy to assemble

Something I worked up from Tinkercad ( https://tinkercad.com/things/aXmdGugwINT ). I borrowed the clawfoot design ( https://tinkercad.com/things/2x5aMtWwHrW )and modified it to fit the Printrbot 1405. Simply print 4 of these out and remove the back supports. I painted mine (yes its a bit sloppy) with fingernail polish. Slap 2 on the front and 2 on the rear and you are set! I lined the inside with some blue painters tape to give it enough grip to stay on firmly. The underside has a cavity to put in some rubber bumpers to keep your Printrbot from sliding all over the desk! They will also raise it up a bit and allow better airflow to the underside to help keep everything cool on longer prints!

comments.text: Hi. If you're planning to print props using a consumer 3D printer using FDM (building layers of melted ABS/PLA filament, i wouldn't recommend it. an ABS printed part has a fraction of the durability of molded ABS due to the nature of FDM. PLA is an even worse proposition. It's brittle and breaks have sharp edges.

description.text:
the nescafe coffee capsule machine we bought would only accept nescafe original capsules.
my wife likes organic coffee and the capsules are approx 2/3rds the size and would not fit.
1st idea was to make an adapter that the smaller capsule fitted into and that fitted into the original tray,
so i reverse engineered the original tray so that the smaller capsules will work.
1st print would not fit, but did a remeasure and mk2 will be printed next week. when complete and checked will upload the STL.
OK version 3 is successful and uploaded

title: Lightweight end effector plate for Delta

description.text:
Parametric, lightweight plate for an end effector for Delta-style printers. Accepts groove mount with a novel snap-in mechanism. Accepts magnets (ball-on-rod designs).  
Built for Eric Sammut's Prometheus hotend, but should work for many others including E3D and aluhotend and really any hotend that mounts its fan directly to the heat sink. With minor modification, fan mounts could be added to this plate.  
In the future, I want to build a version which raises the hotend to avoid losing build volume.  
UPDATED: resolved the long render time and minimized a few more dimensions.  
BIG UPDATE: I changed a few things about the design to make it lighter; also, I want to point out that I am using this part every day now and it works great. I have included an STL. The eventual goal of this plate is to be able to compensate for disparate diagonal rod lengths using the end effector plate to offset the magnets, as well as facilitate easy tool change-outs. The former would be accomplished by extracting the rod lengths out of a pointcloud of bed touches for a fully-calibrated printer. If anyone has any ideas for how I can recess the end effector (maybe somehow by raising the groove mount?) let me know.

description.text: made with http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/smoothie-3d-modeling/
This model has been done with www.smoothie-3d.com

If your telescope is larger than your 3D printer, look no further :) This is a parametric Bahtinov focusing mask split into two or four sections so you can fit your printer. It is based on brentb's original one-piece design. The Bahtinov mask is a focusing aid for astronomy, and is particularly useful for astrophotograpy. The orignal creator is Pavel Bahtinov. A good description is available here: http://www.nightskyimages.co.uk/bahtinov_mask.htm The design shown is for a 224mm (8 inch) mask optimized for a focal length of 1000mm. You probably will want to use the Customizer or the OpenScad file to optimize the mask for your particular telescope. A calculator for optimum Bahtinov design factors is available here: http://astrojargon.net/MaskGenerator.aspx There was a problem with printing the 4th segment when using the customizer which is now fixed. It always worked fine in OpenScad.

Black is the natural colour for this design, to make the blocked sections as dark as possible.  
The first layer can be tricky if you build on kapton, since it is very easy for the single lines to become unstuck and mess up the build. I built with 0.4 mm outer walls to reduce the number of single unconnected lines in the initial layer. Also, starting with a really thick first layer may help. I used a layer height of 0.25 and an initial layer heigh of 0.40.  
After having built the sections, for stability you will probably want to glue the sections together.

description.text: made with http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/smoothie-3d-modeling/
This model has been done with www.smoothie-3d.com

This is an invention to cool down the plastic that comes out of the hot end with cool enviromental air ( room temperature). This is very good for printing small objects faster. Also I experienced that it's possible to print about 30mm in horizontal direction.
So you can setup the bridge distance in slic3r to a bigger distance and it's easier to remove these after printing :-) The electric controll is based on the Gcode conrolled Fan Mod of Ian Johnson (http://solidoodletips.wordpress.com/2012/10/26/gcode-controlled-extruder-fan/)
but instead of a Fan i used a relais that switches an air pump for aquaria. there are really cheap ones for only 10Euro ( about 13$). I designed the Tubes (i wasnt supposed to look like .... ! :D ) and they really fit very well with a glue simply made of Aceton and ABS plastic.
Also it looks good when you paint them in copper or iron colours. ;-)

You need : -Air pump ( i used a 66 Gallons/hour, 5Watt, Membranepump, bought at Amazon for 10Euro)
( http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=air+pump+aquarium&rh=i%3Aaps%2Ck%3Aair+pump+aquarium )
-All the parts for Ians Guide ( but not the fan)
( http://solidoodletips.wordpress.com/2012/10/26/gcode-controlled-extruder-fan/ )
-12V DC relais (you have to take a look how much power your pump has to buy a relais that can switch that power.
-A flexible tube (inner diameter 4mm, outer 6mm)
-A glue that dry´s very quick. I used a acetone and ABS mixture. For the electric part you just have to follow Ian Johnsons guide but instead of connecting the Fan you connect the 12V relais ( you can also use a transistor or something like that ;-) ) . Take a look at the scam for detailed informations.
After the hardware is connected, its very important to set up the controll of your "fan" (in our case the air pump). I can only say how to adjust it in the Slic3r Menu (which Repetier-Host uses for example) : Go in your Slic3r Settings->Filament Settings->Cooling
Then you do the following adjustments:
-Fanspeed minimum to 100
-Fanspeed maximum to 100
-Bridges fan speed to 100%
-Disable fan for the first 1 layers ( maybe adjust to 2, you have to see how the layer behave) I exchanged my Hot Head against this one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33152 from tek so if you have another hot head you may have to customize this cooler tube system. If you have any questions, just ask me per pm or in the Comments. P.S. : Sorry for my bad english, but i learned it in school 10 years ago :)

title: GantryCNC
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
CNC or 3D printing - the final tool head is not set in stone yet.
Updated to make the SCAD/MCAD Library usage more standard.
Now with Customizer Support!
Added cutouts for the motor mounts, and cleaned up a few spots.  Also, started work on a 2d projection for export to dxf for making diagrams for actually building it.

The base design idea for the drive elements and linear rails/bearings came from:
http://letsmakerobots.com/node/9006 This is an early design, and has not been built yet. I want to post it early to make it easy to share with friends and I am opening seeking comments from people who have built something like this and might be able to see some pitfalls a newbie would miss. The OpenSCAD file is fully parameterized, to easily adjust the dimensions of the final machine. The default values I am working with create a working volume of appoximatley 10.5 inches wide, 17 inches long, and 6.5 inches high. I also have it set up the design to 'control' the device so that it is easy to visually observe the range of movement and check for areas where parts might collide. The design is missing any kind of end-stop at the moment, and I haven't drafted in the connections between the drive rods and the axes. The main construction material is 3/4" MDF. The current plans are based on the lumber being actually 3/4" - I haven't adjusted that for the actual dimensions yet, but thanks to OpenSCAD, that is just one variable (BaseBoardThickness) to change. The bearings are 608 rollerblade bearings, and the motors are set as NEMA14's. I am planning on using 8mm ACME threaded leadscrews if I can get them, otherwise I will go with standard 8mm metric threaded rods. My biggest worry so far is that I built in routed out shapes on each of the axes to make is easy to keep the drive rod in close to the axis of movement and keep the off-axis torque down. Will the wood still be strong enough? I am hoping that the slots for the T-Slot rails can be cut into the machine mostly by itself. An Arduino with any one of the available drive software packages and motor drivers will be used to control it. The MCAD Motors library is required for the stepper motor. The library set is available from http://github.com/elmom/MCAD . You can adjust the path in the include statement at the top of the file based on where you install it.

comments.text: I did some construction trials but found that the rails were not reliable enough for mounting a tool on.  I don't recommend building this.  I am not planning to update it further, as I have moved on to other projects.  I sure learned my way around OpenSCAD in the meanwhile.

Effectively are the DryLin type, specifically are IGUS RJZM-02-08.

Advantage: very silent, no lubrication needed, smooth movement.
Disadvantages if there is one: it needs more accurate alignment, but this implies better accuracy.

Printed in PLA at 0.2 mm 10% infill using rafts, but I guess it is not so important.  
Fold where weak to obtain triangular prism shape. Used rubber bands (looms) to keep structure and add more color.  
Make two colored using change filament at z-height (poor man dual extrude).

This OpenSCAD script can generate variations on Oscar ReutersvÃ¤rd's 1934 optical illusion. My approach was inspired by a picture of Artur Tchoukanov's model that I saw in the news (which in turn was inspired by Ulrich Schwanitz). Unfortunately, the news article didn't include the math behind the illusion's construction (they so rarely do!), so I had to rederive everything from scratch. Fortunately it took only a few minutes of basic geometry. This program demonstrates the math behind the illusion; it can generate triangles of arbitrary size and complexity. After some research, it seems that all these figures are in fact inspired by the work of Marcel Duchamp, who was producing impossible-figure photographs by playing with concavity/convexity as early as 1950. Duchamp's techniques are presented alongside the ReutersvÃ¤rd illusion in this 2004 article: http://www.toutfait.com/online_journal_details.php?postid=1375 I learn something new every day!

Open the file in OpenSCAD and adjust the N, S, and T parameters.  Remember to check your toolpaths before attempting to print -- this script will happily produce unprintable results if you're not careful!
I'm hoping to improve printability so that I can use the N=2 version (middle image at left) as a part holder on my desk.

description.text: A little clip to hold your SD card adapter nearby when you're not using it.

I had initially intended this to hold the SD card square with the printbed, but I had made the tolerances too tight for the card to fit in as is. I think it actually works out better with the card at an angle, as it makes it easier to remove, but you could make it fit as intended by widening the slot by around 1Â mm. Also, the fit onto the bed is very tight. If you want to make this a little easier, you could widen the gap between the legs by around 1Â mm and reducing the width of the clips by around 0.5Â mm each. Printed as is, you may need to do some filing work on the legs (or sheer brute force) to get this onto the bed, but it shouldn't take too long. The upside of the fit being so tight is that this doesn't rattle at all when the printer is in use. Finally, to save material without impairing the function of this clip would be to halve the length of this clip as, when mounted at 45Â degrees, the SD card only protrudes into the slot about 50% of the length.

author: PH_X

title: 25°(ish) tilt Jar (Ø74mm x 120mm) Rack for Seperation and Settling

description.text:
Ok so now proving the principle of strip mining, I decided it's time to upscale the operation and upscale the design. Where as before I was using an Anchovy Jar I've decided to use an "Uncle Ben's Sweet and Sour" Jar. This has a 74 millimetre diameter main body and a 54 millimetre diameter base. The height is approximately 120mm. Before I was using the jars for the Anchovies and I was doing the rack at 45 degrees. I've decided that's a bit impractical for this job this size so I did a quick sketch and basically took a line which I decided should be parallel between the top points of the base rack. This was a long build took about 6 hours and I think it highlights a problem with slicer 3 and my RepRap clone. This seems to be the axis scaling, I think there is a mm or so drop between the top point of the jaw and the bottom point which effectively makes the angles not 90 degrees. I'm a bit disappointed with this and it's only really show itself up on this model so far as you can see with the method I'm trying to get everyone to use for printing 90 degree pipe work at 45 degrees to the build platform this would exasperate the problem and make it known round non round. I've voice typed this and it's gonna need a hella lot editing to make this publishable. This is part of my new years resolution of 1 design per day going onto an open source website. So far this is only been in thingiverse, I'm thinking of other websites because I am realising there are problems with document management systems on thingiverse. I would like a little bit more knowledge capture I wonder if someone from thingiverse would care to comment on this (below?) and possibly talk to me about what we need here. So far new years resolution is going well I'm printing things I need and letting other people have copies of them. I know there isn't an airplane on here so far and I Know there are the clichéd hooks that everyone seems to print on 3d printers. But these are specific hooks for aluminium slot section beams. They are actually being used at my place of work at this moment.# This was designed from scratch, but based on:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:621728
45° Spice Rack for Ø45mm Jar Settling and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:623002
45° Spice Rack for SQUARE CSec 45mm Jar Settling 25°(ish) Tilt Jar (Ø74mm x 120mm) Rack for Seperation and Settling Robotics bath robotic by Eur Ing Andy Southern.

author: 3DWP

title: Tap Flap - Clean as you go!

description.text:
A flap for my kitchen tap which has more form than function. The little handle means the same soiled hands turning the water on will touch it after washing. Note, I am not mysophobic lol! However I'm tired of having to wash the handle all the time.  
This flap, designed with an offset to counter the tap arm swinging, allows pushing on one side, and closing the tap with the other side when done. I'm not sure how many people have similar taps, so I'm mainly sharing this as a design idea. If you have a similar tap and it works for you too, let me know! :)

Disclaimer:
Due to the recent incidents (things appearing on ebay) I just want to make something very clear:
I do not allow any commercial use of my STL-files, my designs and my photos! Description:
I prefer cars that are powerfull, rare and a little bit cranky - in short, I like english sportscars.
Since some time ago I am a proud owner of a TVR Cerbera 4.5 - a monster that tries to kill its driver each time you take it for a ride. Lovely! For my toolboxes I needed some TVR logos (never drive an english car without tools), so I made one.

Just print it.
For those who have two hot ends I added a split version.
If you have an Ultimaker put 190mm black PLA in your bowden tube and then feed your Ultimaker with a different color. Print the badge with a layer hight of 0.1mm and 100% fill. This will give you a black base with colored letters on top like I showed in my pictures.

I needed this hole pattern for a dual-extruder mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6632 I couldn't just extrude the original .DXF in OpenSCAD, so I sat down and took precise measurements and created my own replica instead. Completely parametric, if you need to adjust any of the dimensions yourself, but this does include a perfect set of dimensions and boltholes, which I'll be applying to the MK5 Wade's-style tensioner shortly. Marked WIP because it's the official home of the Dual-Extruder mount .SCAD.

Do whatever you want. I don't think this'll be useful for many people directly, just the bolt/hole pattern. UPDATE: Ok, the word is out. Ever since I published this, it secretly also contained the plans for this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6632 And still does, if you need them. UPDATE: .scad file updated for dual mount version. boltholes unchanged.

title: D.E.I.S.S. Dual Extruder Interfacing Single Stepper (Robo3D)

description.text:
The D.E.I.S.S. extruder provides a dual extruder with only one stepper motor by the help of an RC servo. This makes it possible to realize a dual direct drive extruder which is lightweight and space efficient, it's only slightly bigger than a wade extruder. Because it is a direct driven extruder with PTFE tube, it is possible to use flexible filament as well as PLA or ABS. The extruder was designed for the Robo3D printer, but could be adapted to many printers by adapting the x-carriage. This guide will describe how to assemble the DEISS and how to integrate it to a printer at the example of the Robo3D. An adaption of the firmware is required to drive the extruder, since this concept is new, it is not prepared in Marlin firmware, the changes are documented in this guide. Disclaimer: I am not responsible in case of damage, use the guide at your own risk. Features
• Direct drive dual extrusion
• Body fully printable
• Compact setup, comparable to stock wade extruder
• Low mass due to single motor setup
• Nozzle level mechanism
• Quick extruder change setup
• Supports flexible filament Thanks to Ziggy from Robo3D forum, he helped me at the firmware adaption. Video link:
https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B23UvxnhJJDIN08tTEtKOVFST3c/edit?usp=docslist_api Forum link:
http://community.robo3d.com/index.php?threads/d-e-i-s-s-dual-extruder-interfacing-single-stepper.4361/
PDF setup guide included in download

comments.text: Hi Stargrove1, I am planning on building this extruder to work with a Kikailabs Fabber M11. Can you provide the STEP files so I can modify them in solidworks? I will then upload the files here and of course credit you for the originals :) thanks!
comments.author: pablacho

comments.text: Hi Pablacho,
comments.author: pablacho

comments.text: Hi Stargrove1, thanks for the answer! I have found a way to reproduce the models in solidworks, so I am good with the stl files. Why did you stopped using it? It looks like it performed pretty well!
comments.author: Stargrove1

comments.text:
Ok, great, then I don't have to search for the files ;-)
Actually, I never had an application for dual material/color printing. Since it is pretty bulky and I loose some centimeters in height, I decided to switch to a single extruder again.
comments.author: pablacho

comments.text: I've been busy getting Marlin ready for this type of extruder. Please give this a try at your earliest convenience:
comments.author: thinkyhead

comments.text:
Hi, I'm working on modifying a Robo3D printer to work with carbon fiber which requires the use of a cutting mechanism, and I was hoping to modify this servo setup for that. What software are you using for this, and how is the switching of the head done in the software / gcode?
Thanks!
comments.author: tpchuckles

comments.text: Hi, there is no special software required, I run the Robo with the Marlin firmware and Repetier. The firmware must be modified to dual extrusion (see my guide for necessary changes). You can also find the code required to control the servo. About the gcode, it gets created by the slicer automatically, there is a code to switch to second extruder.
comments.author: tpchuckles

comments.text:
thanks! so the switching is handled the way it normally is in Gcode, with T0 and T1, and the firmware modifications handle the servo, the head shift over, and reverse rotation direction?
Thanks!
comments.author: Stargrove1

comments.text: Yes exactly, standard gcode for dual extrusion is used . The part added to the marlin_main moves the servo and instead of adding code to reverse the stepper, I connected the second extruder to the same output with reversed direction.
comments.author: tpchuckles

comments.text:
Thanks for the help! I have mine all set up (printing the last components overnight, and all the circuitry is set up). For my power source I had an apple usb phone wall charger that someone left at my house, which spits out 5.1V, 2A, which is good for all but the peak max torque (which i'm not close to for my setup). I also hear you can wire up multiple lower-currant 5V power sources (I have a ton of old broken phone chargers laying around) in parallel to get to your required current.
cheers
comments.author: Stargrove1

comments.text: I'm glad that I could help you. I'm also curious to see what you are building there.
comments.author: tpchuckles

comments.text: Would you mind if I adapted this to fit the standard X-carriage on the MendelMax 2.0? I'm waiting on parts to build my MM2.0 still, but I'm looking at the 3d models currently. Looks like the servo would have to be placed above the stepper motor as well as some mods to the "Base" to fit the mounting locations. Do you see any issues with that setup or suggest any improvements to your current design?
comments.author: heglet

comments.text:
Feel free to adapt the design for your needs. You may have a look at this one (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:673816), it has the servo on top already. I don't think that there will be any problems, I just wanted to avoid losing additional space on top, while having an empty area below. Also the servo is closer to the belt.
I am struggling with oozing of the nozzle, but I don't know how to improve this. I would use a drive gear pulley of a MK8 extruder because of the bigger diameter to have less way to travel and therefor more force from the servo. I plan an update when the Chimera/Cyclops from E3D arrives.
comments.author: heglet

comments.text: Thanks Stargrove1! Is there any way you could provide nurbs neutral format 3D files like STEP? That would be easier to modify. I use PTC Creo 2.0 (native files are always welcome).
comments.author: Stargrove1

comments.text: I have sent you a message about the files.
comments.author: heglet

comments.text: I checked the chimera / cyclops at the product page, I am afraid that it will be not that simple, point one it different distance between the two nozzles, that would be possible to adjust. But point two is a bigger problem, they were designed for bowden setup, the fixture must be redesigned. I think with a little time effort, both points could be solved.
comments.author: Stargrove1

comments.text: Thanks :)
comments.author: Stargrove1

comments.text: Thanks a lot for this design, it looks fantastic! And the instructions are really great too!. Do you think this can be easily adapted for the cyclops \ chimera when they're released?

author: Franky90

title: Orifice Reducer for Schacht Bulky Flyer

description.text:
Wobbly plying got you down?  Print up two of these pieces to restrict the size of the orifice on your Schacht bulky flyer.  Reduces the orifice to the same size as the hole on a Schacht non-bukly flyer allowing you to take advantage of the increased bobbin capacity.  
Prints in two pieces so that you don't have to break your singles to put it on or take it off!  Neck is angled to allow for printer and flyer variances.
Print two copies of the .stl, clamp around your singles, push into the bulky orifice and enjoy the ride!

I have designed this thing because I could not find anything on here for me to print. I get annoyed when I have to try and find a place to put my phone while using my laptop anywhere but a table. This eliminates the need to worry about that. It tilts up and down and left and right. I have not put rotation in to the design. I may change it at some point. the hanger for the laptop part is over sized for my laptop so that I could attach some soft adhesive backed feet to the inside so that it does not scratch the laptop. The thickness of my screen is 9mm for my Sony VAIO flip 15. It works well with a thinner asus Vivotab 11.6 as well. So it should work for many other laptops. If not, I will upload different backs to conform to other sizes if needed. The back piece is interchangeable so that I could just redesign that one part. I may make it mechanically adjustable at some point. But I get bored too easy and mov e on to the next project.

I printed with supports and at 10% infill and .2 layer height. Worked well with a little to clean out. Because I printed with such little plastic, I brushed the ABS with acetone to make sure it stayed together.
You will need 2 3mm x 25mm screws and wing-nuts to tighten. that's what I used, but you could use whatever you feel like on your print.
The front is designed to only go down enough to be parallel with the screen, but can adjust up and to the left and right to compensate for light reflections.

Divider for a Plano model 3770 storage box. My box did not have enough dividers but a ton of points to use them in so I designed my own. Printed at a 0.2mm layer height and using the line infill @ 10% in Slic3r. I have printed 6 of these so far and they are holding up great and fit just as well as the molded ones do. They consume about 5 grams of material +/- a few grams and print on my Prusa i3v in about 20 minutes including heat up and cool down time.
